Earlier this week, NEWS & NOTES discussed allegations that the Civil Rights Division is not hiring black lawyers.
We talked to Teresa Lynn, a retired civil rights analyst in the division's voting rights section, and she resigned in protest after more than 30 years on the job.
The atmosphere had become one of, oh, mistrust among some of us.
There was control, there was fear of retaliation, and there was a disparate treatment of the analysts based on race.
The Department of Justice accepted our invitation to respond to Lynn's allegations.
Cynthia Magnuson works for the department's office of public affairs, and I asked her if it's true that only two of the current 35 attorneys working in the voting rights section are black.
The Civil Rights Division has an outstanding record of hiring minorities.
The voting section in the Civil Rights Division is one of 10 sections.
And over the past five fiscal years, 27 percent of the new attorney hires in the Civil Rights Division were minorities.
And an important point to make is that this is nearly triple the national average of minority representation in the legal perfection - profession, which the ABA says is about 9.7 percent.
And, of course, we can do better, but we're doing very well now compared to the national average.
And we certainly cast a wide net when we look for new attorneys, and always are open to people from all different diverse backgrounds.
But specifically about African-Americans, because the voting section was really, in some ways, in response to issues of civil rights that affected the African-American community.
Do you know how many are African-American?

Attorneys in the section, I don't think that Mr. Rich is incorrect in saying that, but it's also important to talk about the productivity of the section, which has been extremely good on behalf of all minorities over the last six fiscal years.

So you've mentioned that the recruiting efforts and 27 percent minority hires in recent times - Teresa Lynn mentioned that she thought the quality of lawyers brought into the DOJ had lowered, and she said that the new attorneys don't have an interest in civil rights issues in the same way as the past.
What are your thoughts on that?
You know, that's completely unfounded and unfair.
We hire the best and brightest attorneys that are available, and we will continue to do so.
And when hiring attorneys, we certainly measure three important things among others when we're evaluating these candidates in the Civil Rights Division.

And that's whether they've demonstrated a record of excellence, whether they are talented attorneys consistent with that excellent record, and whether they share a commitment to the work of the division.
And that's very important to us.
We certainly consider diverse backgrounds when hiring folks.
Again, Teresa Lynn, who we spoke with - retired civil rights analyst - compared in an email the atmosphere to a plantation.
And she makes no bones about sending it out and saying that her email was cut off, as she was retiring.
She blamed the voting section chief and deputy section chief for the tone of the office.
Have you received any complaints - either formal and legal or indirect - about the tone of interactions dealing in that section?
You know, I can't comment on some of the specific allegations that Ms. Lynn made.

I will say that in any large organization - there's some 700 employees in the Civil Rights Division - there are going to be individual grievances, and that we do have robust mechanisms in place to resolve allegations of unfair and untoward treatment.
But in reference to the email that was sent, in reality, there are many minorities who are working in the section who have indicated that they were deeply offended by that email.
And I think it's also important to note that Ms. Lynn's direct supervisor is a minority - female - and that's an important point to make.

One allegation that Teresa Lynn made that we didn't put on the air was about the party of hires, that there appear to be more Republican identified new hires as attorneys than in the past, and that it was preponderance.
Do you track that, and what are your statistics on that?
Certainly not.
I mean, again, when we're making hires, we measure their experience.
We measure their excellence.
We measure their commitment to the work.
That is irrelevant to the hiring process.

And does the Justice Department have any plans to address the larger concerns about hirings and firings, most recently given the resignation of the deputy attorney general, and to speak more to the public about the current debate over the issues affecting the department?

You know, Farai, I'm going to tell you that's kind of out of my purview in order what to address, but we're certainly have been engaging folks and talking about this and talking about diversity very proactively and very productively.
Cynthia, I want to thank you so much.
Okay.
Thank you very much.
That was Cynthia Magnuson from the Department of Justice Office of Public Affairs.
This month we're featuring a series focusing on music set in the lower frequencies.
Today we put the spotlight on the bass clarinet.
If you're not familiar with the instrument, just picture an ordinary clarinet stretched down to the floor with its bell curved upward, or a giant peace pipe with its bowl on the ground.
It sounds like this.
(Soundbite of music)
Let me see something here for a second.
(Soundbite of music)
That's the lowest tone that I can play.
That's the virtuoso bass clarinetist Bennie Maupin.
He played with Herbie Hancock on the seminal electric fusion band, Headhunters.
But the first time Maupin played the bass clarinet on a record was in 1969 for Miles Davis on the groundbreaking album "Bitch's Brew.
People ask me about it all the time wherever I go.
(Soundbite of music)
If I bring the bass clarinet out and I haven't played it, they just look at it and say, what is that?
From the very first time that I played it I realized that I loved it because I love the low frequencies.
The fact that you can hear very clearly the overtones and you can also hear very clearly the undertones.
(Soundbite of music)
I became fascinated by that and I practiced it and practiced it a lot, and then I started to come out and actually play it.
At that time was a member of McCoy Tyner's group.
(Soundbite of music)
One night when I was playing with McCoy, Miles came and he heard me play it.
(Soundbite of music)
Bitch's Brew," this recording that created so much controversy in the late 60s, is the very first recording where I actually played the bass clarinet.
And so when I got this call from his office to come be at Columbia Studios at a certain day, I thought it was going to be for the saxophone but it was not; it was for the bass clarinet.
And I think one of the reasons that Miles liked the bass clarinet is because it represents the exact opposite end of the sound spectrum from the trumpet.
And that enables you to have a tremendous amount of contrast.
Plus, it's just a totally alien sound.
You just don't hear it in that way.
(Soundbite of music)
Miles never really said anything about what he wanted.
One morning he said something to me, it was kind of shocking.
He looked at me and he said, why don't you play?
I can't think of anything.
And this is Miles Davis saying this to me.
You know, he would just motion to me, just go ahead.
Just play whatever you like.
And he loved it.
(Soundbite of music)
Once I heard that recording, then I realized that I was totally free to do whatever I like with the instrument, and it was the perfect instrument to experiment on.
And I glad that it happened the way it did, because career-wise I established a totally unique voice for myself.
(Soundbite of music)
I think because it is made from wood that has a lot do to with it.
The resonance is what really sort of captures you.
In a lot of the music we hear on the radio we hear high frequencies a lot.
They use the soprano saxophone or the alto saxophone.
And of course you hear guitar.
But it's the low frequencies that have this tremendous power to really pull you in.
They automatically force you to listen.
